posts.name: Jacob
posts.cooked:
This year, my team is using a bot that has a rotatable arm, and even with break-mode turned on on our Spark Maxes, we still get a little bit of drift in the arm because of the extensive weight. I know that similar functionality of holding the arm stationary can be reached through a PID Loop, so I have tried creating a PID Subsystem that can hold the arm stationary. In my main teleop command, I have it so that if the driver is not pushing down a button that lifts the arm, then the arm is held stationary. Competition is coming up, and I am having a lot of trouble getting this functionality integrated into our robot. I have attached my code below. When I run my useOutput() method in my teleop command, it does not work the way I intend it to. Could I get some help with getting this to work before my team goes to competition soon? When our motor drifts, the Spark Max velocity is about 45, so that is why I used 10 for my tolerance value. I used 0 for my setPoint because the value I am using is the arm motor velocity, so I want the setPoint to be 0 rotations. When I get the subsystem laid out properly, I would also love some guidance on how to work with the PIDSubsystem in my command to get the arm to be stationary. Thank you so much for your help! It means a lot!

ArmPID.java (2.3 KB)

posts.name: Ishaan Masilamony
posts.cooked: Add some feedforward to your control loop. That will help account for the weight and should improve precision as well

posts.name: Jacob
posts.cooked: I got the PID Controller to act on the arm, but I am having trouble tuning my variables. I am using an ElevatorFeedforward. I have 6 variables to tune, so I am struggling tuning those variables simultaneously. I saw a video on Ziegler-Nichols Method where I just had to work with the Kp until it has constant oscillations and then create the Ki and Kd from that, but it’s not working. I broke one of our gear boxes while trying to tune this motor, so I am getting really nervous about tuning going forward. We are using NEO Brushless motors REV 21-1650 with a 50:1 gear ratio. Can I get some guidance on tuning?

posts.name: usbcd36
posts.cooked:
Plug the info on your arm into reca.lc and see what it says.  If it shows oscillations, you probably need to change gearing first.

Plug the info on your arm into reca.lc and see what it says.  If it shows oscillations, you probably need to change gearing first.

Keep in mind: the mechanical properties of your arm set an upper limit on how good your tuning can be .

Keep in mind: the mechanical properties of your arm set an upper limit on how good your tuning can be .

Try your hand at tuning this simulation , which won’t break your robot.

Try your hand at tuning this simulation , which won’t break your robot.

Use ArmFeedforward . More explanation on the difference between Elevator- and ArmFeedforward. You must make pi/2 radians correspond to the arm pointing up (i.e., gravity isn’t trying to rotate it).  If you don’t, feedforward won’t work properly.

Use ArmFeedforward . More explanation on the difference between Elevator- and ArmFeedforward. You must make pi/2 radians correspond to the arm pointing up (i.e., gravity isn’t trying to rotate it).  If you don’t, feedforward won’t work properly.

Send the position, position setpoint, velocity, PID output, and feedforward output to Glass and plot them while tuning.  Use these to inform your tuning choices.

Send the position, position setpoint, velocity, PID output, and feedforward output to Glass and plot them while tuning.  Use these to inform your tuning choices.

Start with just kG, and kV (for ArmFeedforward), and kP (on your PID controller).  Zero out all of the other constants.  Tune them in this order: kG, kV, kP.  Ideally, pull the constants from Glass too; redeploying code every iteration eats your tuning time.

Start with just kG, and kV (for ArmFeedforward), and kP (on your PID controller).  Zero out all of the other constants.  Tune them in this order: kG, kV, kP.  Ideally, pull the constants from Glass too; redeploying code every iteration eats your tuning time.

When it’s tuned properly, you want the feedforward output to be much bigger than the PID output.

When it’s tuned properly, you want the feedforward output to be much bigger than the PID output.

Consider using a ProfiledPIDController to limit the acceleration and velocity of the setpoints. Example (it’s for an elevator, but if you replace the ElevatorFeedforward object, it’s the same)

Consider using a ProfiledPIDController to limit the acceleration and velocity of the setpoints. Example (it’s for an elevator, but if you replace the ElevatorFeedforward object, it’s the same)
